content:
A previously tight-lipped city is co-operating with police over the attack

THE SHOT that killed Lyra McKee, one of Northern Ireland’s most promising young journalists, was fired by a youth urged on by embittered ancients still convinced that Irish republicanism can prevail only through the barrel of a gun. Leaders of the so-called New IRA, which has admitted responsibility for the murder, persuaded the unidentified killer that mainstream republicans had betrayed their followers by swapping violence for politics. Yet in so doing, they have gravely damaged their cause.

The killing of Ms McKee, hit by a stray bullet as she watched rioting in Derry/LondonDerry on April 18th, has caused shock waves. Her funeral in Belfast on April 24th was attended by the heads of the British and Irish governments, as well as a host of local politicians. Such an impressive turn-out is meant to show how determined they are to avoid any return to the terrible sectarian violence that plagued Northern Ireland for three decades.

That Ms McKee died on the eve of the anniversary of the Good Friday Agreement, which brought an end to the Troubles in 1998, has only underlined what is at stake. Increasingly acrimonious Brexit negotiations have raised tensions, particularly as regards the vexed question of the Irish border. No one wants to return to a “hard border” when  Britain leaves the European Union, which would undermine the peace agreement. Neither will hardline Tory Brexiteers nor the Democratic Unionist Party accept the backstop solution to keep the UK in a customs union and apply some single-market regulations to Northern Ireland alone. This is meant to avert any risk of a hard border, but having different rules for the province and for Great Britain raises fears in the DUP of more intrusive border checks in the Irish Sea.  

No one expects a return to violence of the scale seen in the Troubles, whatever Brexit or any other development may bring. By the time it disbanded in 1998 the IRA had killed more than 1,700 people. Dissident republicans, who never accepted the peace and who now exist as a number of unco-ordinated splinters, have since then killed fewer than 100. This is enough for the security services to rate their threat as “severe”. But the “micro-groups”, as Sinn Fein, the main republican party, dismisses them, lack the experience or skills to maintain an effective and sustained campaign.

Their incompetence nonetheless makes them dangerous in other ways. This has recently been illustrated twice in Derry, with Ms McKee’s killing and, in January, the detonation of a car bomb in a busy street following a warning of only 30 minutes. The device could easily have caused civilian deaths or injuries. Dissident republicans also claimed responsibility for a number of parcel bombs posted to British addresses last month. The riot that Ms McKee was observing was sparked by police raids which gave the Dissidents an excuse to blood young men in the arts of street warfare. The presence in the city of a TV camera crew may have given them an extra incentive to bring out a few guns.

So-called loyalist paramilitary groups represent a different sort of threat, still roaming the backstreets of Belfast but these days less interested in sectarian violence than everyday gangsterism. Since the end of the Troubles they have devoted themselves to lining their pockets through drug-dealing, loan-sharking and extortion in Protestant ghettoes. In January an east-Belfast man who had fallen foul of a loyalist organisation was murdered by a five-man gang who stabbed him in the back 11 times.

Attacks like this, as well as occasional beatings, bricks through windows, and so on, continue. But over the years the pattern has been that acts of terrorism which result in the death of civilians cause widespread revulsion and lead to a dip in terrorist activity.

Ms McKee’s killers have issued an apology, even if they have shown little sense of real remorse. But they do appear shaken, for they are well aware that deaths like hers are bad for their cause. The Derry offices of Saoradh, a political party supported by the New IRA, were smeared with red handprints by protesters. “Not in our name” was painted beneath a local republican mural. Police said that by the end of the Easter weekend over 140 people had come forward to offer information on the killing—a “sea change” in a city that has historically been reluctant to pass on information regarding republicans of any stripe. Many Derry doors which were once opened to dissidents may now be shut in their faces.

ex: n. 火花；电火花；火星；活力
